deliberation: I evaluated whether the violent images (falling by the sword, infants dashed, pregnant women ripped open) were hyperbolic or figurative. In prophetic warfare contexts these are standard literal siege atrocities, so I treat them as literal threats rather than hyperbole. The primary figurative element is the use of the place-name Samaria to stand for the people and leadership of the northern kingdom.

instances.english_text: Samaria must bear her guilt, for she has defied her God.
target: the people and rulers of the northern kingdom of Israel
ground: the capital represents and embodies its inhabitants and their policies
representative relationship (part/center for whole)
political symbolism of cities for nations
posture: using the capital’s name to indict the whole people
rhetorical accusation
prophetic judgment discourse
instances.explanation: The city-name “Samaria” stands metonymically for the entire northern kingdom—its people and leadership—who are said to be guilty and rebellious.

deliberation: I looked for metaphors and idioms in the call to return and the description of falling. The verse uses a common prophetic metaphor of repentance as physical returning and another metaphor of moral failure as stumbling/falling; both are clear figurative uses of motion imagery.

instances.english_text: Return, O Israel, to the ETERNAL your God
target: Israel’s repentance and renewed loyalty to God
vehicle: physically returning to a person or place
ground: moving back toward someone restores nearness and relationship
a change of course back to a former point
restoration of proximity after separation
posture: urgent invitation to come back under God’s authority
exhortative appeal
prophetic call to repentance
instances.explanation: Israel’s act of repentance is depicted metaphorically as physically returning to God, using movement imagery for spiritual and relational change.

instances.english_text: For you have fallen/stumbled because of your sin.
target: Israel’s moral and national collapse due to sin
vehicle: a person stumbling and falling while walking
ground: loss of stability and collapse brought on by a misstep
disorientation, injury, or downfall following a stumble
vulnerability when one’s footing is lost
posture: explanatory statement of how sin leads to ruin
didactic warning
prophetic diagnosis of their plight
instances.explanation: Israel’s condition is portrayed as someone who has stumbled and fallen because of iniquity, using bodily movement as a metaphor for moral failure and its destructive results.

deliberation: I examined the commands to take words, the request to remove iniquity, and the phrase about repaying bulls with our lips. The two clearest figures are: (1) words conceptualized as objects that can be taken along like offerings, and (2) a strong metaphor equating spoken confession/praise with sacrificial bulls.

instances.english_text: Take words with you and return to GOD
target: the prayers/confessions Israel is to bring before God
vehicle: portable items that can be carried along
physical objects borne in one’s hands or on one’s person
ground: intentional preparation and bringing of something valuable to present
words treated as offerings or gifts carried into an audience
transfer of something from the worshiper to God
posture: positive reorientation from animal sacrifices toward verbal offerings
instructional tone
prophetic guidance on how to approach God
instances.explanation: Words are pictured as tangible items that can be taken along to God, evoking offerings carried into His presence; this conceptualizes prayer as something physically borne to God.

instances.english_text: Instead of bulls we will pay [the offering of] our lips (literally: we will pay bulls [with] our lips).
target: Israel’s spoken confession, praise, and prayer
ground: both bulls and sincere words are costly, intentional offerings meant to honor God
substitution of verbal sacrifice for animal sacrifice
communication with God as a gift or payment of what is due
posture: shifting devotion from external ritual to heartfelt speech
penitential but hopeful commitment
theological revaluation of sacrifice
instances.explanation: Lips’ offerings—prayer and confession—are metaphorically equated with paying sacrificial bulls, casting spoken worship as the true sacrificial payment to God.

deliberation: I checked whether the political statements about Assyria and horses are figurative; they appear straightforward. The clearly figurative expression is “work of our hands” used for idols, which is a metonymy where the product stands for a specific class of religious objects.

instances.english_text: Nor ever again will we call our handiwork our god
target: man-made idols that Israel has worshiped
vehicle: products of human labor and craftsmanship
ground: idols are literally products crafted by human hands
producer–product relationship allows the product to stand for the specific kind of object (idols)
emphasis on their human, not divine, origin
posture: critical exposure of idols as merely human-made
repudiation of former idolatry
polemical stance against false gods
instances.explanation: The phrase “work of our hands” stands metonymically for the idols themselves—human-crafted objects that had been wrongly called ‘our god.’

deliberation: I looked at the promise to heal, the vow of love, and anger turning away. The verse uses (1) a medical metaphor of healing for restoring from apostasy and (2) a personification/metaphor of God’s anger as something that can turn away like a moving person.

instances.english_text: I will heal their affliction/turning away (apostasy)
target: Israel’s apostasy and its damaging effects
vehicle: a physical illness that needs healing
ground: apostasy is a harmful condition that weakens and endangers life
healing restores wholeness and proper function
need for a competent healer to reverse the condition
posture: tender, restorative commitment by God
promise of cure rather than mere punishment
pastoral aspect of prophetic speech
instances.explanation: Israel’s spiritual waywardness is described as an illness God will heal, using medical imagery for moral and relational restoration.

instances.english_text: For My anger has turned away from him

posture: assurance that judgment has been withdrawn
compassionate relenting
movement from wrath to favor
instances.explanation: God’s anger is personified as something that can ‘turn away’ like a person changing direction, depicting the cessation of active wrath toward Israel.

deliberation: This verse is rich with explicit similes: God compared to dew, Israel to a blossoming lily, and Israel’s roots compared to Lebanon’s deep-rooted trees. I treated each comparison as a distinct simile, with Lebanon functioning metonymically for its famous forests in the third image.

instances.english_text: I will be to Israel like dew

ground: dew quietly and regularly nourishes plants in dry climates
refreshment and sustenance without violent force
indispensable support for life and growth
posture: highly positive, nurturing image
promise of gentle restoration
reversal of earlier judgment imagery
instances.explanation: God portrays Himself as dew, highlighting His gentle, sustaining, and life-giving influence on a spiritually dry Israel.

instances.explanation: Israel’s restoration is likened to a lily blossoming, emphasizing the beauty and vitality that will follow God’s renewing work.

instances.english_text: He shall strike root like a Lebanon tree (literally: like Lebanon)

the cedars of Lebanon were proverbial for sturdiness
firm establishment in a place

counter to earlier imagery of uprooting and exile
confidence-building promise
instances.explanation: Lebanon, metonymically standing for its great trees, provides the simile: Israel’s roots will be as deep and secure as those famed forests.

deliberation: I noted three images: shoots that ‘go’, splendor like the olive tree, and fragrance like Lebanon. The verb ‘go’ is a personifying growth metaphor, while the latter two are explicit similes comparing Israel’s restored state to the olive’s beauty and Lebanon’s aroma.

instances.english_text: His boughs/young shoots shall spread out (literally: shall go)

organic, living expansion rather than mechanical increase
visible indication of health and vigor
posture: positive projection of dynamic growth
hopeful outlook for Israel’s future reach
comforting reassurance
instances.explanation: Israel’s growth is described through personified plant imagery—young shoots that ‘go’ or spread, conveying organic expansion and vitality.

instances.english_text: His beauty shall be like the olive tree’s

a pleasing and sturdy appearance

emphasis on lasting, not fleeting, beauty

instances.explanation: Israel’s beauty is compared to that of the olive tree, invoking the tree’s valued, enduring, and fruitful character for Israel’s renewed honor.

instances.english_text: His fragrance shall be like that of Lebanon
target: renown and experiential quality of the community
vehicle: Lebanon, noted for its fragrant forests
pleasant aroma of cedar and mountain air
ground: a delightful fragrance draws and pleases others
Lebanon’s scent was proverbially fresh and pleasing
attractiveness perceived even at some distance
posture: highly affirmative portrayal of Israel’s restored standing
from stench of sin to fragrance of blessing
reversal of earlier negative imagery
instances.explanation: Lebanon stands metonymically for its fragrant forests; Israel’s renewed reputation is likened to that pleasant aroma, signaling an attractive, life-giving presence.

deliberation: I evaluated the ‘shade’, grain revival, vine blossoming, and wine of Lebanon. ‘Sitting in his shade’ is a protection metaphor; ‘blossom like the vine’ and ‘memory like wine of Lebanon’ are explicit similes linking Israel’s prosperity and renown to viticultural images. I treated ‘revive grain’ as primarily literal agricultural renewal and did not count it as a separate strong figure.

instances.english_text: They who sit in his shade

proximity to the sheltering source is necessary to benefit
posture: promissory image of safe refuge within the restored order
positive, inviting picture of life under protection
contrast to earlier exposure to judgment
instances.explanation: To ‘sit in his shade’ metaphorically depicts enjoying protection and refreshment under the shelter of the restored Israel (ultimately under God’s care).

instances.english_text: They shall blossom like the vine
target: the community’s economic and social flourishing
prosperity and growth of those under God’s favor

beauty and productivity combined

reversal of barrenness and loss
encouraging assurance to the hearers
instances.explanation: People under God’s renewed favor are compared to a blossoming vine, highlighting abundance, beauty, and productivity.

instances.english_text: His scent/renown shall be like the wine of Lebanon

wine’s aroma and taste can symbolize refined delight
Lebanon’s produce was associated with excellence

from shame to something savored and celebrated
vision of enduring, delightful remembrance
instances.explanation: Israel’s renown is likened to Lebanon’s wine—metonymically symbolizing a refined, delightful, and prized reputation in the eyes of others.

deliberation: I considered whether the statement about idols contained irony, but it is straightforward renunciation. The two clear figures are: (1) God depicted as a verdant cypress, and (2) the claim that Israel’s ‘fruit’ comes from God, using fruit as a metaphor for all results and blessings.

instances.english_text: I am like a verdant cypress

contrast to lifeless idols
invitation to trust in His enduring nature
instances.explanation: God compares Himself to a green cypress, emphasizing His enduring, sheltering, life-filled character over against transient idols.

instances.english_text: Your fruit is provided by Me (from Me your fruit is found)

instances.explanation: Israel’s benefits and achievements are metaphorically called ‘fruit,’ explicitly said to come from God as the tree-like source that enables their existence.

deliberation: I examined the wisdom exhortation and the description of the ways of YHWH. The entire second half of the verse is an extended path metaphor: God’s ways are ‘paths’; the righteous ‘walk’ in them; transgressors ‘stumble’ on them. I treated this as two closely related but distinct expressions—secure walking versus stumbling—within one conceptual PATH metaphor.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּי־יְשָׁרִים דַּרְכֵי יְהֹוָה וְצַדִּקִים יֵלְכוּ בָם
instances.english_text: For the paths/ways of GOD are smooth/straight; the righteous can walk on them
target: God’s moral will and providential dealings

ground: a straight, level path allows safe, unimpeded walking

conformity to the path’s direction brings security
posture: didactic commendation of living according to God’s ways
wisdom encouragement to choose the right path
affirmation that God’s order is not crooked or treacherous
instances.explanation: God’s ‘ways’ stand metonymically for His moral will and dealings, and life under that will is depicted as walking on straight paths on which the righteous can move securely.

instances.english_text: While sinners stumble on them
target: the experience and fate of those who rebel against God
response of transgressors to God’s moral order
vehicle: a person stumbling and falling on a path
misstep leading to injury or delay
ground: careless or defiant walking on a path leads to stumbling

posture: warning that misuse of God’s ways leads to downfall
paradoxical note: what is safe for the righteous trips the wicked
wisdom observation about divergent responses to the same divine order
instances.explanation: The same ‘paths’ of God that the righteous navigate securely become places of stumbling for transgressors; moral failure is pictured as tripping and falling on a road.
